title: Great Railroad Strike
description: The Great Railroad Strike of 1877 began in Baltimore and spread nationwide, marking the first major labor uprising in American history. Workers protested wage cuts amid economic depression, leading to federal troops being deployed to restore order.
modernConnection: This strike set precedents for federal intervention in labor disputes and highlighted tensions between workers and corporations that persist in today’s union organizing and gig‑economy debates.

sources.title: Library of Congress: The Great Railroad Strike of 1877

title: Edison's Electric Light Bulb Patent
description: Thomas Edison received his patent for the incandescent light bulb in Menlo Park, New Jersey, revolutionizing lighting and laying the foundation for the electrical industry.
modernConnection: Edison's research model and infrastructure buildout prefigure modern R&D ecosystems and platform technologies.

title: Standard Oil Trust Formation
description: John D. Rockefeller formed the Standard Oil Trust in Cleveland, creating a dominant monopoly that controlled most U.S. oil refining.
modernConnection: Standard Oil’s consolidation catalyzed antitrust law—paralleling today’s concerns about platform dominance in big tech.

title: Interstate Commerce Act
description: Congress created the Interstate Commerce Commission to regulate railroad rates and curb unfair practices—an early federal step toward regulating big business.
modernConnection: Establishes a template for sector‑specific regulation and independent commissions used throughout the 20th century and today.

title: Haymarket Affair
description: A labor rally in Chicago for the eight‑hour day turned violent, leading to fatalities and the trial of anarchists; it became a defining moment for the labor movement.
modernConnection: Shapes global labor commemoration (May Day) and frames ongoing debates over policing, protest, and worker rights.

title: Homestead Strike
description: Steelworkers struck at Carnegie’s Homestead mill; a violent clash with Pinkertons and state militia ensued, weakening organized labor in heavy industry.
modernConnection: Highlights the power imbalance between large firms and labor—echoing in today’s debates over unionization in logistics and tech.

sources.title: Homestead Strike – Encyclopedia of U.S. Labor

title: Sherman Antitrust Act
description: Congress passed the first federal law aimed at curbing trusts and monopolies.
modernConnection: Provides the legal backbone for modern antitrust enforcement against dominant platforms and mergers.

title: Ellis Island Opens
description: The federal immigration station at Ellis Island opened, processing millions during peak industrial growth and urbanization.
modernConnection: Frames debates over immigration policy, labor supply, and American identity that persist today.

sources.title: Statue of Liberty – Ellis Island Foundation

title: Panic of 1893
description: A severe economic depression led to bank failures and mass unemployment, intensifying calls for monetary and regulatory reforms.
modernConnection: Early test of federal capacity to stabilize finance; foreshadows later central banking and crisis responses.

sources.title: Federal Reserve Education: Panics of the 19th Century

title: Pullman Strike
description: A nationwide railroad boycott led by Eugene V. Debs was broken by federal injunctions and troops; the Supreme Court upheld broad use of injunctions against labor.
modernConnection: Precedents for federal intervention and labor law continue to shape organizing and strike strategy.

title: J.P. Morgan Forms U.S. Steel
description: J.P. Morgan created U.S. Steel by consolidating Carnegie Steel and others—the world’s first billion‑dollar corporation.
modernConnection: Establishes the model for mega‑mergers and corporate finance that persists into the era of trillion‑dollar firms.

title: Wright Brothers First Flight
description: Orville and Wilbur Wright achieved the first powered flight at Kitty Hawk, launching the aviation age.
modernConnection: Innovation in aviation set the stage for global connectivity and modern aerospace industries.

sources.title: Wright Brothers Papers – Library of Congress

title: Northern Securities Co. v. United States
description: The Supreme Court ordered the dissolution of the Northern Securities railroad trust—early proof that the Sherman Act could break up monopolies.
modernConnection: A key precedent for structural remedies in antitrust—relevant to platform breakups today.

sources.title: Northern Securities Co. v. U.S., 193 U.S. 197 (1904)

title: Pure Food & Drug and Meat Inspection Acts
description: Congress enacted consumer protection laws to regulate food and drug safety and meatpacking, responding to public outcry and muckraking exposés.
modernConnection: Foundation for the FDA and modern consumer protection regimes.

title: Model T Production Begins
description: Ford began mass production of the Model T in Detroit, making automobiles affordable for ordinary Americans and transforming transportation and manufacturing.
modernConnection: Mass production techniques inform today’s automation, supply chains, and EV scaling.

title: Upton Sinclair’s The Jungle
description: Publication of The Jungle exposed unsanitary conditions in meatpacking and labor exploitation, galvanizing public support for federal regulation.
modernConnection: Illustrates the power of investigative journalism to drive policy change—echoed in modern consumer and workplace reporting.

title: Hepburn Act
description: The Hepburn Act strengthened the ICC’s power to set maximum railroad rates and extended its jurisdiction—deepening federal regulatory capacity.
modernConnection: Precedent for rate‑setting and oversight of network industries (e.g., telecom, utilities).

title: Federal Reserve System Created
description: The Federal Reserve Act created America’s central banking system to provide financial stability and regulate monetary policy.
modernConnection: The Fed remains central in crisis response and inflation control, evident in 2008 and COVID‑19 policy.

title: Triangle Shirtwaist Factory Fire
description: A factory fire in New York City killed 146 workers, spurring major workplace safety reforms and labor protections.
modernConnection: Catalyst for building codes and occupational safety; frames today’s supply‑chain and workplace standards.

title: World War I Begins
description: World War I began in Europe; U.S. neutrality gave way to entry in 1917, cementing America’s global industrial and military capacity.
modernConnection: WWI accelerated federal coordination of industry and labor—templates for later mobilizations and today’s emergency economic policies.

title: Standard Oil Breakup
description: In Standard Oil Co. v. United States, the Supreme Court ordered the dissolution of Standard Oil under the Sherman Act.
modernConnection: Archetype of structural antitrust remedies, frequently cited in debates over breaking up dominant tech platforms.

sources.title: Standard Oil Co. v. United States, 221 U.S. 1 (1911)
